headline.main: The Case Against Banning Chocolate Milk

docs.abstract: Eliminating chocolate milk from school cafeterias has become a quick-fix answer to our childhood obesity problem, but easy answers aren't always the right ones.
docs.snippet: Eliminating chocolate milk from school cafeterias has become a quick-fix answer to our childhood obesity problem, but easy answers aren't always the right ones.

headline.main: The Case Against Banning Chocolate Milk

docs.abstract: Eliminating chocolate milk from school cafeterias has become a quick-fix answer to our childhood obesity problem, but easy answers aren't always the right ones.
docs.lead_paragraph: Here's the clearly very sensible Penny McConnell of the Fairfax County school system, in Virginia, on chocolate milk: "Banning a food may not be as helpful as the more complicated task of teaching kids to look at their whole plates, and make good choices."
docs.snippet: Eliminating chocolate milk from school cafeterias has become a quick-fix answer to our childhood obesity problem, but easy answers aren't always the right ones.

headline.print_headline: Phys Ed: Feeling Fat in Those Genes? Exercise May Help
headline.main: Staying Trim When Fat Runs in the Family

docs.abstract: Physical activity, even in small doses, may help subvert the effects of the so-called fat gene, a new study reports.

headline.main: Staying Trim When Fat Runs in the Family

docs.abstract: Physical activity, even in small doses, may help subvert the effects of the so-called fat gene, a new study reports.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just in time for Thanksgiving, a major new study offers some hopeful news about fat and fate, as well as about the consequences of the choices we make.

headline.main: BPA Lurks in Canned Soups and Drinks

docs.abstract: People who ate canned soup had more than a tenfold increase in BPA, a chemical that some think may be linked to cancer and other ills.
docs.snippet: People who ate canned soup had more than a tenfold increase in BPA, a chemical that some think may be linked to cancer and other ills.

headline.main: BPA Lurks in Canned Soups and Drinks

docs.abstract: People who ate canned soup had more than a tenfold increase in BPA, a chemical that some think may be linked to cancer and other ills.
docs.lead_paragraph: A new study by Harvard researchers may provide another reason to skip the canned pumpkin and cranberry sauce this Thanksgiving. People who ate one serving of canned food daily over the course of five days, the study found, had significantly elevated levels -- more than a tenfold increase -- of bisphenol-A, or BPA, a substance that lines most food and drink cans.
docs.snippet: People who ate canned soup had more than a tenfold increase in BPA, a chemical that some think may be linked to cancer and other ills.
